work.p: Draft titled "Old Age Recitatives" written on the verso of an envelope and a letter (author unknown) stuck together. Beneath the main title and Whitman's signature is another title, "Sail out for good, Eidólon yacht!" The text of the poem is identical to the published version of "Sail Out for Good, Eidólon Yacht!"

titleStmt.title: Old Age Recitatives
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was likely composed in 1890, as "Sail Out For Good, Eidólon Yacht!" was published in 1891. The envelope on the verso is also postmarked 1890.
On the verso is an envelope addressed to Whitman, postmarked received in Camden, Jan 21, 1890. The envelope is glued to a portion of a letter (author unknown) requesting an autograph.

lg.head:
Old Age
Chants
Recitatives

note.p: the editor sent word sneeringly by he already had "a great lot of poetry on hand"

lg.head: Sail out for good, Eidólon yacht!
lg.l:
O little white-hull'd sloop, now speed on
really deep waters,
(I will not call it our concluding voyage,

But outset and sure entrance to the truest,
best, maturest;)

Depart—depart from
s
olid earth—no more
returning to these shores,

Now on for aye our infinite free venture
wending,

Spurning all yet tried ports, seas, hawsers,
densities, gravitation,
Sail out for good, eidólon yacht of me!
